chapter.title: Restricting and Granting Access to the Machine
chapter.para: This chapter presents information about restricting access to the system using firewalling and encryption and gives information about connecting to the system remotely.

sect1.title: Configuring &susefirewall;
sect1.para: By default, the installation workflow of &sles4sap; enables &susefirewall;. The firewall needs to be manually configured to allow network access for the following:

listitem.para: Database (see the documentation of your database vendor; for &hana;, see )

sect1.para: SAP applications require many open ports and port ranges in the firewall. The exact numbers depend on the selected instance. For more information, see the documentation provided to you by SAP.

sect1.title: Configuring HANA-Firewall
sect1.para: To simplify setting up a firewall for &hana;, install the package HANA-Firewall. Whereas standard &susefirewall; allows only three zones (internal, DMZ, and external), HANA-Firewall enables you to configure more zones to accommodate all running &hana; instances.
HANA-Firewall works by adding rule sets to your existing &susefirewall; configuration.
HANA-Firewall consists of the following parts:

formalpara.title: &yast; Module SAP HANA Firewall
formalpara.para: Allows configuring, applying, and reverting firewall rules for &hana; from a graphical user interface.

formalpara.title: Command-Line Utility hana-firewall
formalpara.para: Allows applying and reverting the configured firewall rules for &hana;.

listitem.para: If you prefer, you can configure the rule sets using the configuration file at /etc/sysconfig/hana-firewall instead of using &yast;.

formalpara.title: Service hana-firewall
formalpara.para: Ensures that configured firewall rules for &hana; are kept.

important.title: Multi-Tenant Databases
important.para: For multi-tenant &hana; databases, determining the port numbers that need to be opened is not yet possible automatically. If you are working with a multi-tenant &hana; database system, before you use &yast;, run a script on the command line to create a new service definition:
You need to switch to the directory /etc/hana-firewall.d, otherwise the rule file for the new service will be created in a place where it cannot be used.
The script will ask several questions: Importantly, it will ask for TCP and UDP port ranges that need to be opened.

step.para: Make sure the &hana; databases for which you want to configure the firewall are correctly installed.
To open the appropriate &yast; module, select ApplicationsYaST , Security and Users SAP HANA Firewall.
When you open this &yast; module, it will create a configuration proposal based on the number of installed &hana; instances.
In the module, set the Number of network interfaces in this HANA setup.
Choose an Interface number and its corresponding network interface name (for example, eth0).
Allow network services by selecting them in the list box on the left and clicking Add. Remove services by selecting them in the list box on the right and clicking Remove.
To add services other than the preconfigured ones, add them using the following notation:
For more information about the CIDR notation, see . To find out which services are available on your system, use getent services.
When you are done, click Next.
The firewall rules from HANA-Firewall will now be compiled and applied. Finally, the service hana-firewall will be restarted.
Finally, check whether HANA-Firewall was enabled correctly:
step.screen: &prompt.root;hana-firewall status HANA firewall is active. Everything is OK.
